questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to a local hospital in the village after an aspiration for a small toy. On examination, there is significant respiratory distress . An emergency tracheostomy is done after seeking consent. Any of the following can get damaged during the emergency tracheostomy, except?

A 34-year-old female presents with complaints of pain and numbness in the perineal region, as well as difficulty with urination and defecation. Physical examination reveals decreased sensation in the perianal area and weakened anal sphincter tone. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected?

A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain and back pain. He reports a history of hypertension and smoking. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute. He appears pale, sweaty, and agitated. Abdominal examination reveals diffuse tenderness and guarding with absent bowel sounds. A pulsatile mass is palpable in the midline of the abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Initiate IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics

options.label: B
options.text: Order an abdominal CT scan and consult vascular surgery

options.label: C
options.text: Administer morphine for pain relief and observe the patient

options.label: D
options.text: Transfer the patient to the ICU for hemodynamic support

questions.correct_answer: B. Order an abdominal CT scan and consult vascular surgery
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Information

Location

In the abdominal cavity, extending from the diaphragm to the pelvis

Origin

Begins at the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm, at the level of T12 vertebrae

Type

Major artery of the systemic circulation, part of the descending aorta

Parts
  • Suprarenal segment (located above the renal arteries)
  • Infrarenal segment (located between the renal arteries and the aortic bifurcation)
  • Retrorenal segment (located behind the renal arteries)
  • Peri-renal segment (located around the renal arteries)

Branches
  • Inferior phrenic arteries
  • Celiac trunk (supplies the liver, stomach, spleen, and pancreas)
  • Superior mesenteric artery (supplies the small intestine, cecum, and ascending colon)
  • Renal arteries (supply the kidneys)
  • Inferior mesenteric artery (supplies the descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum)
  • Lumbar arteries (supply the lumbar vertebrae, spinal cord, and back muscles)
  • Middle sacral artery (supplies the sacrum and coccyx)
  • Gonadal arteries (supply the gonads, i.e., testes in males and ovaries in females)

Diseases/Disorders
  • Atherosclerosis (commonly affects the abdominal aorta, leading to plaque formation, narrowing of the vessel lumen, and reduced blood flow)
  • Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)
  • Aortitis
  • Embolism or thrombosis of the abdominal aorta
  • Dissection of the abdominal aorta

Symptoms if Damaged
  • Abdominal or back pain (most common)
  • Pulsatile abdominal mass (in case of AAA)
  • Limb ischemia (in case of embolism or thrombosis)

* Imaging techniques such as ultrasound, CT scan, and MRI are commonly used for evaluation of abdominal aortic diseases

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the emergency department with lower gastrointestinal bleeding and abdominal pain. After diagnostic workup, the child is diagnosed with a Meckel's diverticulum with the presence of gastric mucosa. The surgical team decides that surgery is necessary to address the issue, and the child is scheduled for immediate surgical intervention. During the surgery, the surgeon discovers that Meckel's diverticulum has become inflamed.. What is the most likely complication associated with this finding during the surgical intervention?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Location

Small intestine (ileum), typically near ileocecal valve

Type

True diverticulum, containing all layers of intestinal wall

Pathology
  • Blind pouch with narrow neck and pouch-like dilation (2-4 cm length)
  • May contain heterotopic tissue (e.g. gastric mucosa)

Causes

Failure of omphalomesenteric duct closure during fetal development

Etiology

Congenital anomaly, present from birth

Symptoms

Often asymptomatic, but can present with abdominal pain, bleeding, obstruction, inflammation

Diagnosis

Imaging studies (e.g. Meckel scan, CT scan, barium studies, endoscopy)

Management

Symptomatic cases may require surgical resection, asymptomatic cases may be managed conservatively with monitoring

Complications

Bleeding, obstruction, inflammation, perforation

Association

May be associated with omphalocele, umbilical hernia, gastrointestinal bleeding

Age of presentation

Most commonly presents in childhood, but can occur at any age

Gender predilection

Slightly more common in males

Incidence

Approximately 2% of the population has Meckel's diverticulum

Other info

Most common congenital abnormality of gastrointestinal tract, may mimic other conditions such as appendicitis or Crohn's disease

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, fever, and elevated white blood cell count. On examination, he has diffuse tenderness and guarding over the abdomen. CT scan reveals thickening and infiltration of the greater omentum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Information

Location

Hangs down from the greater curvature of the stomach and extends over the anterior surface of the intestines in the abdominal cavity

Origin

Derived from the dorsal mesentery, attached to the greater curvature of the stomach and the first part of the duodenum

Type

Double-layered peritoneal fold with an anterior and a posterior layer

Functions
  • Immune defense
  • Fat deposition
  • Tissue repair
  • Adhesion prevention

Diseases/ Disorders
  • Omental torsion: Twisting of the omentum on itself, leading to ischemia and infarction.
  • Omental abscess: Collection of pus in the omental tissue due to infection.
  • Omental hernia: Protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect in the omentum.
  • Omental metastasis: Spread of cancer cells to the omental tissue from other primary sites.
  • Liposarcoma: Malignant tumor arising from adipose tissue in the omentum.

Symptoms if damaged

Abdominal pain, nausea, weight loss, signs of infection or malignancy

Other relevant information
  • Referred to as "policeman of the abdomen"
  • Used in certain surgical procedures for tissue repair

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals thickened gastric folds with nodular mucosa. Biopsy specimens show cystic dilation of the gastric glands with a lack of parietal cells and an increase in mucous cells. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals overexpression of transforming growth factor-alpha (TGF-α) in the gastric mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Information

Definition

Rare condition with hypertrophy of gastric mucosa, excessive mucus production, and foveolar hyperplasia.

Causes
  • Usually unknown
  • Might be associated with,
    • Viral infections
    • Autoimmune reactions
    • Genetic predisposition

Pathology

Hypertrophy of gastric mucosa with enlarged gastric folds, excessive mucus production, and foveolar hyperplasia.

Etiology

Imbalance between mucosal cell regeneration and apoptosis, leading to hyperplasia of gastric mucosa and increased mucus production.

Clinical Presentation
  • Early satiety, edema
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Abdominal pain

Complications
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Increased risk of gastric malignancy
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding

Diagnosis
  • Upper endoscopy with biopsy to visualize enlarged gastric folds and confirm foveolar hyperplasia.
  • Testing for Helicobacter pylori infection
  • Ruling out other causes of gastric hypertrophy
  • Assessing for complications

Treatment
  • Supportive management
  • Proton pump inhibitors to reduce gastric acid secretion
  • Nutritional support and blood transfusion in severe cases
  • Surgical resection in select cases
  • Follow-up endoscopy
  • Surveillance for gastric malignancy

Prognosis

Risk of gastric malignancy increased, particularly in older individuals with persistent symptoms or extensive gastric involvement (variable)

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a history of progressive swelling and pain in her right upper extremity. She has a history of thoracic outlet syndrome and was previously treated with physical therapy. A CT scan shows compression of the right brachiocephalic vein. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

Compression of the brachiocephalic vein, often due to anatomical structures in the thoracic outlet

Location

Compression usually occurs in the thoracic outlet, which is the space between the clavicle, first rib, and scalene muscles

Causes
  • Congenital abnormalities like cervical rib, anomalous muscles, or fibrous bands
  • Acquired causes like trauma, repetitive overhead activities, tumors, or inflammation

Pathology

Compression of the brachiocephalic vein leads to impaired venous return from the upper limb

Etiology
  • Congenital: Presence of cervical rib, anomalous muscles, or fibrous bands
  • Acquired: Trauma, repetitive activities, tumors, inflammation

Risk Factors
  • Congenital abnormalities like cervical rib or other anatomical abnormalities
  • Overhead activities or repetitive arm motions
  • History of trauma to the thoracic outlet or surrounding structures

Clinical Features
  • Arm swelling, pain, and discoloration
  • Symptoms worsen with arm elevation and improve with arm dependency
  • Visible collaterals over the shoulder and upper chest

Diagnostic Procedures
  • Duplex ultrasound to visualize the venous anatomy and blood flow
  • CT scan or MRI to identify anatomical abnormalities, tumors, or inflammation

Associations
  • Thoracic outlet syndrome
  • Venous thrombosis in the upper limb
  • Compression of adjacent nerves or arteries

Management
  • Conservative measures like avoiding triggering activities, using compression stockings
  • Medications like anticoagulants may be prescribed if venous thrombosis is present
  • Surgical intervention may be considered in severe cases, such as removal of cervical rib or fibrous bands

*Brachiocephalic vein gives rise to subclavian veins on both sides, which then merge to form the superior vena cava

questions.text: A 3-year-old male presents with back pain, cloudy urine, and painful urination for 1 month. Ultrasound shows bilateral renal calculi and metabolic evaluation reveals marked hypercalciuria with normal calcium, magnesium, phosphate, uric acid, and creatinine levels, leading to a diagnosis of idiopathic hypercalciuria. What dietary management is appropriate?

A 9-year-old boy is brought to an outdoor department with a history of decreased urine output, cola-coloured urine, and swelling of the face and hands for 2 days. On examination, he is hypertensive, has a puffy face, and pitting oedema of the lower limbs but is vitally stable. He has a history of skin lesions 4 weeks earlier. A diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is made. ASO titers, in this case, will be?

options.label: D
options.text: Initially elevated, rapidly fall in 3-4 days

questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Definition Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a type of acute glomerulonephritis, which is a form of kidney inflammation. It occurs following an infection with certain strains of group A Streptococcus bacteria, particularly after a streptococcal throat or skin infection, such as strep throat or impetigo.
Causative Organism Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) is the causative organism responsible for PSGN. After the infection, the body's immune response produces antibodies, including antistreptolysin O (ASO), which can be measured through laboratory testing. Elevated ASO titers indicate a recent or recent past streptococcal infection.
Pathophysiology After the initial streptococcal infection, the immune system mounts an immune response, leading to the production of immune complexes. These complexes can deposit in the glomeruli (small filtering units) of the kidneys, triggering inflammation and damage to the kidney tissues, resulting in glomerulonephritis.
Clinical Presentation - Hematuria (blood in the urine)
  - Proteinuria (excess protein in the urine)
  - Edema (swelling), especially around the eyes, hands, and feet
  - Hypertension (high blood pressure)
  - Oliguria (decreased urine output)
  - Dark-colored, foamy urine
Diagnosis - Clinical history and physical examination
  - Laboratory tests: Elevated ASO titers, increased anti-DNase B titers, and decreased serum complement levels (C3 and C4) are typical findings.
  - Urinalysis: Presence of red blood cells and protein in the urine.
  - Renal biopsy (rarely required): To confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of kidney damage.
Treatment - Supportive care: Rest, adequate fluid intake, and management of hypertension and edema.
  - Antibiotics: Antibiotics may be given to treat the underlying streptococcal infection and prevent further complications.
  - Diuretics: To help manage fluid retention and edema.
  - Antihypertensive medications: To control blood pressure if necessary.
  - Dietary adjustments: Limiting salt and protein intake may be beneficial in some cases.
Prognosis Most cases of PSGN have a good prognosis, especially in children. The majority of patients recover fully with supportive care and appropriate treatment of the underlying infection. In some cases, especially in adults with underlying health conditions, PSGN can lead to more severe kidney damage and may require further management.
Complications - Acute kidney injury
  - Chronic kidney disease
  - Hypertensive encephalopathy (rare)
  - Pulmonary edema (rare)
  - Heart failure (rare)

options.text: The dissolution of the chromatin within a cell's nucleus

options.label: C
options.text: The rupture of the cell's membrane

options.text: The clumping of nuclear material within a cell's cytoplasm

questions.correct_answer: B. The dissolution of the chromatin within a cell's nucleus
questions.explanation:
Karyolysis

Karyorrhexis

Structural changes

The chromatin within a cell's nucleus undergoes dissolution and disappears

The chromatin, or the entire nucleus within a cell's nucleus, undergoes fragmentation and disintegration

 

The cell's nucleus may shrink in size or disappear entirely

The cell's nucleus disintegrates and may release its contents

Mechanisms

Karyolysis can be caused by factors such as enzymatic degradation, oxidative stress, and mechanical stress

Karyorrhexis can also be caused by enzymatic degradation, oxidative stress, and mechanical stress but can also occur as a result of other pathological conditions such as inflammation or infection

questions.text: Which among the following ions is responsible for the major currents of depolarization in Purkinje fibers of the heart?

A professor explains nephron physiology and the process of secretion and reabsorption. Tubular reabsorption is the process that moves solutes and water out of the filtrate and back into your bloodstream. This process is known as reabsorption because this is the second time they have been absorbed, the first time being when they were absorbed into the bloodstream from the digestive tract after a meal. Maximum absorption of HCO 3 - occurs in?

options.label: D
options.text: Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Bicarbonate Mechanism
  • ➤ All the filtered HCO 3 – in the renal tubules is reabsorbed. About 80% of it is reabsorbed in proximal convoluted tubule, 15% in Henle loop and 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct. The reabsorption of HCO 3 – utilizes the H + secreted into the renal tubules. H + secreted into the renal tubule, combines with filtered HCO 3 – forming carbonic acid (H 2 CO 3 ). Carbonic acid dissociates into carbon dioxide and water in the presence of carbonic anhydrase. Carbon dioxide and water enter the tubular cell. In the tubular cells, carbon dioxide combines with water to form carbonic acid. It immediately dissociates into H + and HCO 3 – . HCO 3 – from the tubular cell enters the interstitium. Simultaneously Na + is reabsorbed from the renal tubule under the influence of aldosterone. HCO 3 – combines with Na + to form sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO 3 ). Now, the H + is secreted into the tubular lumen from the cell in exchange for Na + . Thus, for every hydrogen ion secreted into lumen of tubule, one bicarbonate ion is reabsorbed from the tubule. In this way, kidneys conserve the HCO 3 –. The reabsorption of filtered HCO 3 – is an important factor in maintaining pH of the body fluids. Filtered bicarbonate can be reabsorbed only when it combines with H + .
  • ➤ All the filtered HCO 3 – in the renal tubules is reabsorbed. About 80% of it is reabsorbed in proximal convoluted tubule, 15% in Henle loop and 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct. The reabsorption of HCO 3 – utilizes the H + secreted into the renal tubules.
  • ➤ H + secreted into the renal tubule, combines with filtered HCO 3 – forming carbonic acid (H 2 CO 3 ). Carbonic acid dissociates into carbon dioxide and water in the presence of carbonic anhydrase. Carbon dioxide and water enter the tubular cell.
  • ➤ In the tubular cells, carbon dioxide combines with water to form carbonic acid. It immediately dissociates into H + and HCO 3 – . HCO 3 – from the tubular cell enters the interstitium. Simultaneously Na + is reabsorbed from the renal tubule under the influence of aldosterone. HCO 3 – combines with Na + to form sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO 3 ). Now, the H + is secreted into the tubular lumen from the cell in exchange for Na + .
  • ➤ Thus, for every hydrogen ion secreted into lumen of tubule, one bicarbonate ion is reabsorbed from the tubule. In this way, kidneys conserve the HCO 3 –. The reabsorption of filtered HCO 3 – is an important factor in maintaining pH of the body fluids.
  • ➤ Filtered bicarbonate can be reabsorbed only when it combines with H + .

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary mechanism of acidification in the stomach?

options.label: A
options.text: Active transport of H+ ions into the stomach lumen

options.label: B
options.text: Diffusion of H+ ions into the stomach lumen

options.label: C
options.text: Secretion of bicarbonate ions into the stomach lumen

options.label: D
options.text: Binding of H+ ions to Cl- ions in the stomach lumen

questions.correct_answer: B. Diffusion of H+ ions into the stomach lumen
questions.explanation:
Factors

Description

Gastrin
  • Hormone released from G-cells in response to stomach distension and the presence of peptides and amino acids. 
  • Stimulates parietal cells to produce acid and increases the rate of gastric emptying.

Histamine
  • Released by enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in response to gastrin and acetylcholine. 
  • Stimulates parietal cells to produce acid.

Acetylcholine
  • Released from nerve endings in response to the smell, sight, or taste of food. 
  • Stimulates parietal cells to produce acid and increases the motility of the stomach.

Somatostatin
  • Hormone released by D-cells in response to acid in the stomach. 
  • Inhibits the release of gastrin, histamine, and acetylcholine, which results in decreased acid secretion.

Prostaglandins
  • Lipid compounds synthesized by the gastric mucosa.
  • Stimulate mucus and bicarbonate secretion 
  • Helps to protect the gastric mucosa from acid damage. 
  • Inhibit acid secretion and increase blood flow to the stomach.

Carbon dioxide
  • Acts as a potent vasodilator and stimulates the release of gastrin and histamine 
  • Stimulate acid secretion.

Helicobacter pylori
  • A bacterium that colonizes the stomach and causes inflammation of the gastric mucosa.
  • Produces urease, which converts urea to ammonia, creating a local alkaline environment (allows it to survive in the acidic stomach).
  • Stimulates the release of gastrin, which increases acid secretion.

questions.text: Mr. J, a 50-year-old male, is brought to the emergency department with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) due to uncontrolled type 1 diabetes. His blood gas analysis reveals a pH of 7.20, bicarbonate (HCO 3 - ) level of 10 mEq/L, and pCO 2 level of 30 mmHg. Which buffer system is likely to be compensating for his acid-base imbalance?

A patient who underwent a gastrectomy complains of feeling full after eating small meals, and also has episodes of vomiting. Upon examination, the patient's gastric pH is found to be elevated. Which of the following best explains these symptoms?

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of the stomach's reservoir function

questions.correct_answer: D. Loss of the stomach's reservoir function
questions.explanation:
The sight, smell, or taste of food stimulates the brain to send signals through the vagus nerve to the stomach.

The signals from the vagus nerve cause the release of gastrin, a hormone that stimulates acid secretion.

Gastrin travels through the bloodstream to the parietal cells in the stomach lining.

When gastrin binds to receptors on the parietal cells, it triggers a series of biochemical reactions that ultimately result in the secretion of hydrochloric acid.

Chloride ions are transported into the lumen of the stomach, where they combine with hydrogen ions (protons) to form hydrochloric acid.

The hydrochloric acid helps to break down food, sterilize the stomach contents, and activate enzymes that are involved in digestion.

The presence of food in the stomach stimulates the release of additional gastrin, which further enhances acid secretion.

As the stomach empties and the pH of the stomach contents rises, the secretion of gastrin and acid gradually decreases.

Cell Type

Function

Parietal cells

Secrete hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factor

Chief cells

Secrete pepsinogen

G cells

Secrete gastrin

D cells

Secrete somatostatin

ECL cells

Secrete histamine

Mucous cells

Secrete mucus to protect the stomach lining

Enterochromaffin-like cells

Secrete serotonin and histamine, which stimulate acid secretion

Measures the time taken for blood to clot in a test tube

Assess the coagulation cascade and factors involved in blood clotting

A prolonged bleeding time may indicate a platelet disorder or a problem with blood vessels

A prolonged clotting time may indicate a deficiency in clotting factors or the presence of anticoagulants

Measured by making a small incision on the skin and measuring the time it takes for the bleeding to stop

Measured by adding a reagent to a sample of blood and measuring the time it takes for a clot to form

Usually takes 2 to 10 minutes in healthy individuals

Usually takes 6 to 15 minutes in healthy individuals

Factors

Increased bleeding time with low platelet count

Prolonged clotting time with low platelet count

Coagulation

Prolonged clotting time with coagulation factor deficiency

Vascular

Little or no effect on clotting time

Medications

Prolonged clotting time with anticoagulants

Hereditary

Increased bleeding time with bleeding disorders

Prolonged clotting time with inherited coagulation disorders

Liver dysfunction

Little or no effect on bleeding time

Prolonged clotting time with liver dysfunction

questions.text: A 42-year-old male is diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) characterized by excessive worry, restlessness, muscle tension, and difficulty concentrating. He has no history of allergies or adverse reactions to medications. The patient's medical history is unremarkable, and he is not currently taking any medications. Which of the following medications is the drug of choice for the initial treatment of generalized anxiety disorder?
questions.explanation:
Definition Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) is a mental health disorder characterized by excessive, persistent, and uncontrollable worry or anxiety about various life situations or events.
Diagnostic Criteria Excessive anxiety or worry about a variety of topics, occurring more days than not for at least 6 months. The worry is difficult to control.
  The anxiety is associated with three or more of the following symptoms: restlessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, irritability, muscle tension, and sleep disturbances.
Prevalence GAD is a common disorder, with a lifetime prevalence of around 5-6% in the general population.
Onset GAD often has an insidious onset and can develop at any age, but it typically starts in childhood, adolescence, or early adulthood.
Etiology Combination of genetic, environmental, and neurological factors contribute to the development of GAD.
Comorbidities GAD frequently co-occurs with other anxiety disorders, depression, substance abuse, and medical conditions.
Treatment - Psychotherapy, particularly Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), is a primary treatment approach.
  - Medications like selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), and benzodiazepines may be used.
  - Lifestyle modifications, stress management techniques, and relaxation strategies are beneficial.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe shortness of breath. On examination, he has decreased breath sounds on the right side and a chest X-ray reveals a large right-sided pleural effusion. Thoracentesis is performed and 1.5 liters of fluid is drained. Despite the drainage, the patient's respiratory distress worsens, and his arterial blood gas shows a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 150. Which of the following best explains this finding?

options.label: A
options.text: The thoracentesis caused the lung to collapse, leading to decreased pulmonary compliance.

options.label: B
options.text: The pleural effusion caused compression atelectasis and decreased pulmonary compliance.

options.label: C
options.text: The patient has developed pulmonary edema secondary to fluid overload.

options.label: D
options.text: The patient has developed a pulmonary embolism, leading to decreased pulmonary compliance.

questions.correct_answer: B. The pleural effusion caused compression atelectasis and decreased pulmonary compliance.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presented with sudden visual loss affecting the right temporal region. Ultrasound of the globe demonstrated right-sided retinal detachment with a well-defined flat echogenic mass. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old female presents with intermittent episodes of crampy abdominal pain and constipation for the past 3 months. She denies any rectal bleeding or weight loss. She has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Physical examination reveals distended abdomen with diffuse tenderness. Laboratory studies show no significant abnormalities. Radiological findings are as below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Colonic volvulus

Colorectal cancer

Hirschsprung's disease

Colonic diverticulosis

"Beak-like" narrowing of the sigmoid colon with proximal dilation.

Masses, polyps, or irregularities in the colonic mucosa on imaging studies such as CT scan or colonoscopy.

Transition zone between the normal and dilated colon.

Multiple, small, round or oval contrast-filled pouches protruding from the colon wall.

questions.text: A 2-day-old male neonate presents with failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, and vomiting. An abdominal X-ray shows the following findings: Image A: X-ray The histopathological examination of the myenteric plexuses is as follows: Image B: Histopath of myenteric plexus What is the most likely radiological diagnosis?

A 2-month-old male infant presents to the emergency department with cyanosis and labored breathing. Physical examination reveals clubbing of the fingers and toes. The infant's mother reports that he has been experiencing poor feeding and decreased energy over the past few weeks. The chest X-ray is as follows: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old male patient presents with a history of fever, malaise, and a painful rash on his trunk and extremities that rapidly spread to involve his mucous membranes, including his oral cavity, eyes, and genitals. The rash started as small blisters that coalesced and formed large, flaccid blisters that easily detached, leaving behind denuded areas of skin. Biopsy results showed full-thickness epidermal necrosis with minimal inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following medications is typically used to treat a pruritic rash with subepidermal blistering and granular deposits of immunoglobulin A (IgA) in the papillary dermis?
questions.explanation:
Dermatitis herpetiformis

Etiology

Dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) is an autoimmune disease triggered by gluten sensitivity.

Clinical Features

Symmetric pruritic papulovesicular rash on the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, back, and nape of the neck.

Diagnosis

Skin biopsy and direct immunofluorescence (DIF) testing of the skin biopsy can confirm the diagnosis.

Pathology

Immunoglobulin A (IgA) antibodies accumulate in the tips of the dermal papillae and are associated with complement and fibrin deposition.

Risk Factors

Individuals with celiac disease are at increased risk for DH.

Treatment

A lifelong gluten-free diet, dapsone, and sulfapyridine are all possible treatments for DH.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented with complaints of chronic diarrhea, weight loss and skin rash. She also reports bloating, abdominal pain, and fatigue. Laboratory studies show iron-deficiency anemia and positive serology for anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Upper endoscopy with duodenal biopsy reveals subtotal villous atrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Empiric treatment for irritable bowel syndrome

questions.correct_answer: A. Trial of a gluten-free diet
questions.explanation:
Celiac disease

Etiology
  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder caused by the ingestion of gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. 
  • It occurs due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors.

Symptoms
  • Bloating
  • Abdominal pain
  • Diarrhea
  • Constipation
  • Fatigue
  • Weight loss
  • Anemia.
  • Skin Rash

Diagnosis
  • The diagnosis of celiac disease involves a series of tests including serological tests, genetic testing, and endoscopy with biopsy. 
  • Serological tests measure the presence of antibodies to gluten in the blood, while genetic testing can identify the genes that increase the risk of developing celiac disease.
  • Endoscopy with biopsy involves taking a sample of the small intestine to confirm the presence of damage to the intestinal lining caused by gluten.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding bullous diseases?

options.label: A
options.text: Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects the elderly and presents with tense blisters on the trunk and extremities.

options.label: B
options.text: Pemphigus vulgaris is a bacterial infection that causes blistering and is commonly seen in children.

options.label: C
options.text: Erythema multiforme is a fungal infection that presents with small, itchy blisters on the arms and legs.

options.label: D
options.text: Dermatitis herpetiformis is a viral infection that causes large, fluid-filled blisters on the face and scalp

questions.correct_answer: A. Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects the elderly and presents with tense blisters on the trunk and extremities.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with 20 pack-year history of smoking presents to the physician's office with a complaint of hoarseness of voice for the past few months. On laryngeal examination, there was an outgrowth covering the vocal cords bilaterally, and the biopsy sample was taken. He was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma of stage T4a and subsequently underwent a total laryngectomy. Which of the following statements are true about total laryngectomy? 1. Usually done for carcinoma larynx 2. Speech difficulty present 3. High tracheostomy is done in total laryngectomy 4. After total laryngectomy, the patient presents with dysphagia

A 70-year-old man presents to the physician's office with a complaint of hoarseness of voice for the past six months. He is a chronic smoker and has a 50-pack-year history of smoking. On physical examination, neck lymph nodes are not palpable; however, laryngoscopy shows a large, infiltrating, fungating, soft papillary lesion. Two biopsies taken from the lesion proper show be­nign appearing papillomatosis with hyperkeratosis and acanthosis infiltrating the subjacent tissues. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A group of medical students gives a presentation on the musculature of the larynx. They describe the muscles of the larynx, their origin and insertion, their action, and innervation . Which of the following laryngeal muscles is/are innervated bi-directionally? Vocalis Posterior cricoarytenoid Lateral cricoarytenoid Interarytenoid

A 25-year-old female of low socioeconomic status visits the hospital with complaints of difficulty swallowing for the last 2 months. On further examination, the patient has spoon-shaped nails . Laboratory investigations reveal microcytic hypochromic anemia . Which of the following is the most probable site of carcinoma in this case?

A 14-year-old male presents to the clinic due to fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing for 3 days. He has a history of tonsillitis, and this is the sixth episode in the past two years. The patient undergoes a tonsillectomy to relieve the symptoms. The patient presents to the clinic again on the seventh day of surgery with bleeding from the surgical site. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Primary               Reactionary            Secondary  

Intraoperative bleed at the time of surgery.

Venous bleedingThe most common source is the paratonsillar vein.

Treatment: Ligation, electrocoagulation of vessels.

Occurs within 24 hours.

Due to slippage of ligature or clot formation preventing clipping of the artery.

Treatment: Application of pressure/ vasoconstrictor, removal of the clot, and lastly, if all measures fail, ligation of vessels.

Between 5-10 postoperative days.

Due to secondary infection (sepsis) or premature separation of membranes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent episodes of epistaxis. On examination, you find anterior nasal bleeding that has not responded to conservative measures. Which of the following is the best management option?
questions.explanation:
Management Approach

Indications

Examples of Drugs and Doses

Special Considerations

Local measures

Mild epistaxis

Pinching nostrils together, leaning forward, cold compress

Useful for initial bleeding control, may not be sufficient for severe bleeding

Topical medications

Anterior epistaxis

Oxymetazoline (Afrin): 0.05-0.1% spray, 2-3 sprays per nostril every 10-12 hours

Other Options: Phenylephrine (Neo-Synephrine)

May cause rebound congestion, contraindicated in certain medical conditions (e.g., uncontrolled hypertension)

Nasal packing

Anterior or posterior epistaxis

Gauze, nasal tampons, or inflatable balloon catheter

Provides direct pressure to the bleeding site, may need to be removed by a healthcare professional

Cauterization

Anterior epistaxis

Silver nitrate sticks or electrocautery

Used to chemically or thermally cauterize bleeding vessels, may require local anesthesia

Nasal artery ligation

Persistent or recurrent epistaxis

Sphenopalatine artery or anterior ethmoid artery ligation

Invasive procedure, may be considered for severe or refractory cases, requires specialized expertise

Embolization

Severe or refractory epistaxis

Embolization of arteries supplying nasal mucosa

Invasive procedure, requires interventional radiology expertise, may be considered when other measures fail

Surgical intervention

Underlying structural abnormalities

Deviated nasal septum, nasal tumors, etc.

Requires appropriate diagnosis and referral to otolaryngologist or ENT surgeon

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with nasal congestion and stuffiness for several weeks. He has been using nasal decongestant sprays frequently for relief. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Topic

Information

Definition

Prolonged and excessive use of nasal decongestant sprays leading to rebound congestion and dependence on the medication.

Causes

Overuse of nasal decongestant sprays.

Symptoms

Persistent nasal congestion worsens with time.

Clinical Features

Stuffy or "blocked" nose, nasal congestion that worsens with continuous use of nasal decongestant sprays, decreased effectiveness of the medication over time.

Complications
  • Nasal polyps
  • Sinusitis
  • Epistaxis (nosebleeds)

Diagnosis

Clinical history, physical examination, ruling out other causes of nasal congestion.

Treatment

Gradual tapering and discontinuation of nasal decongestant sprays.

Drugs Used

Pseudoephedrine (30-60 mg/day) or Phenylephrine (10-20 mg/day) for gradual tapering.

Not Recommended
  • Systemic corticosteroids
  • Antibiotics
  • Antihistamines as the primary treatment.

Prevention

Limiting the use of nasal decongestant sprays to short-term, as per healthcare professional's advice.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with progressive hoarseness of voice and stridor. The child has a history of recurrent respiratory infections since birth. On examination, a congenital laryngeal web is observed. What is the most appropriate treatment modality for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

A rare congenital anomaly characterized by a thin membrane or a thick fibrous band that obstructs the laryngeal inlet, causing respiratory distress.

Causes

The exact cause is unknown, but it may be associated with genetic abnormalities, prematurity, or maternal infections during pregnancy.

Symptoms

Stridor (a high-pitched, harsh breathing sound), difficulty breathing, hoarseness, and recurrent episodes of choking or coughing.

Clinical Features

Mild to severe respiratory distress, depending on the severity and location of the web, and associated with feeding difficulties and failure to thrive.

Pathophysiology

The web develops during embryonic development due to incomplete or abnormal separation of the laryngeal structures.

Diagnostic Findings

Direct laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, and imaging studies such as CT or MRI may be used to visualize the larynx and confirm the diagnosis.

Work Up

A thorough physical examination, medical history, and diagnostic tests are performed to determine the extent of the anomaly and the severity of the obstruction.

Treatment/ Management

Surgical intervention is the primary treatment, and the goal is to establish a patent airway while preserving laryngeal function.

Complications

If left untreated, the condition can lead to severe respiratory distress, failure to thrive, aspiration pneumonia, and even death.

Type

Summary

Type I

The most common type, characterized by a thin, translucent membrane that extends across the anterior commissure of the vocal cords.

Type II

A thicker, fibrous web that involves the anterior two-thirds of the glottis and may extend to the subglottis.

Type III

A complete web that involves the entire glottis and subglottis, leading to severe respiratory distress and life-threatening airway obstruction.

Type IV

A web that involves only the subglottis, causing symptoms such as stridor and hoarseness.

Type

Treatment Plan

Type I

Open laryngoplasty or endoscopic laryngoplasty

Type II

Endoscopic laryngoplasty

Type III

Emergency airway management followed by surgical intervention with laryngotracheoplasty or tracheostomy

Type IV

Treatment plan based on individual patient's needs, which may include medical management, surgical intervention, or both

Cortical/cuneiform cataract

questions.text: A 37-year-old female presents to the OPD with gradual painless vision loss in both eyes over the past three months. She is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis and has been on steroid treatment for the past two years. Her IOP is within normal limits. The red reflex is absent in both eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for an annual physical examination. He reports that his vision has progressively improved over the past 6 months, and he no longer needs the glasses he used while driving. He has hypertension and types 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include glyburide, hydrochlorothiazide, and enalapril. Examination shows 20/20 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows a few microaneurysms of retinal vessels. Which is the most likely explanation for this patient's improved vision?

A 50-year-old female presents to an outdoor ophthalmology department with a history of severe dull pain and redness of both eyes for the last two days. She also complains of discomfort in both eyes while driving at night. A typical butterfly rash on the face spares nasolabial folds on physical examination. Upon further inquiry, the ophthalmologist knows she is a known case of SLE and taking Hydroxychloroquine . The ophthalmologist counsels her that she is suffering from scleritis, which is the inflammation of the white of the eye. Concerning the anatomy, the sclera is the thinnest and thickest, respectively, at which part of the eyeball?

options.label: A

options.label: B

questions.text: Which of the following is not a most common organism for the image given below?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Ophthalmia Neonatorum

Definition

Conjunctivitis occurring in newborns within the first 28 days of life

Causative Organisms
  • Commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections, such as Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • Can also be caused by Herpes simplex virus and other bacteria

Risk Factors
  • Maternal history of sexually transmitted infections
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Low birth weight

Clinical Presentation
  • Conjunctival redness
  • Swelling
  • Discharge (serous, serosanguinous, or purulent)

Complications
  • Corneal scarring
  • Vision impairment or blindness

Diagnosis
  • Based on clinical presentation and history
  • Conjunctival swab for microbiological culture and sensitivity

Treatment
  • Prompt and appropriate treatment with topical antibiotics, such as erythromycin or ceftriaxone, based on causative organism
  • Prophylactic application of topical antibiotics at birth to prevent neonatal conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Other Considerations
  • Ophthalmia neonatorum caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a medical emergency requiring prompt treatment to prevent corneal damage and systemic spread of infection
  • Corneal scarring and vision impairment can occur if left untreated

Organism

Incidence

Prevalence

Chlamydia trachomatis

Varies by region, up to 30% in some settings

Varies by population, up to 5-10% in some populations

Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Generally low, up to 1-2% in limited prenatal care settings

Generally low, up to 5-10% in limited prenatal care settings

Herpes simplex virus

Estimated at 1 in 10,000 live births

Varies widely, around 10-20% in high-risk populations

Other bacteria

Varies depending on local bacterial flora and risk factors

Varies depending on local epidemiology and risk factors

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of dryness and irritation in his eyes. On examination, it is found that his tear film is unstable and there is decreased tear production. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Aspects

Summary

Composition

Three-layered structure consisting

  • Lipid layer (from meibomian glands)
  • Aqueous layer (from lacrimal glands)
  • Mucin layer (from goblet cells of conjunctiva)

Functions
  • Lubrication of the ocular surface
  • Nutrient supply to the cornea
  • Protection against microbial infection
  • Maintenance of tear film stability

Anatomy

Tear film covers the ocular surface, including the cornea and conjunctiva, and is continuously produced by the lacrimal glands, meibomian glands, and goblet cells

Tear Production

Regulated primarily by the parasympathetic nervous system, with stimulation of the lacrimal glands; reduced tear production can result in conditions like dry eye syndrome

Formation of Tear Film
  • Lipid layer is secreted by the meibomian glands
  • Aqueous layer is secreted by the lacrimal glands
  • Mucin layer is secreted by the goblet cells of the conjunctiva

Importance of Tear Film
  • Lubrication: Tear film helps in smooth blinking and prevents friction between the eyelids and the ocular surface
  • Nutrient supply: Tear film supplies oxygen and nutrients to the cornea, which lacks its own blood supply
  • Microbial protection: Tear film contains antimicrobial components that help protect the ocular surface from infection
  • Tear film stability: Proper tear film stability is crucial for maintaining a clear and stable ocular surface, ensuring good vision

Diseases/Conditions
  • Dry eye syndrome: Reduced tear production or increased tear evaporation, leading to inadequate lubrication of the ocular surface
  • Meibomian gland dysfunction: Dysfunction of meibomian glands leading to lipid layer abnormalities
  • Conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the conjunctiva, which can affect the mucin layer of the tear film

Effects of Tear Film Disorders
  • Disruption of tear film stability and lubrication can result in dryness, discomfort, blurred vision, and increased risk of infection
  • Corneal epithelial damage and potential vision loss

Treatment
  • Artificial tears: Lubricating eye drops to relieve dryness and discomfort
  • Meibomian gland expression: Clearing of blocked meibomian glands to improve lipid layer function
  • Anti-inflammatory medications: Topical corticosteroids or immunomodulatory drugs for conditions like conjunctivitis
  • Management of underlying causes or contributing factors, such as lid hygiene, lifestyle modifications, and environmental changes

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with pain and swelling in the thigh. 1st two months
  • Abnormalities in 65-85% cases,

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presents signs and symptoms suggestive of meningitis which has been resistant to antibiotics for his current illness for the last 02 weeks. His MRI brain is revealing ventriculomegaly and a brain abscess. Importantly, he has a pathognomic feature of fungal infection. Later he is suspected of having a fungal disease. His sample was sent for staining and further processing to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is a correctly matched stain in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Stain

Comments

 

Mycology Lab

Calcofluor white

fluorochrome that binds glucans and chit in fungal cell wall;

Lactophenol Cotton Blue

cotton blue (aka analine blue) dye stains chitin and allows visualization of fungal elements following scraping or tape preparation from culture

 

Pathology

Hematoxylin and esoin (H&E)

used to visualize host cell response to fungi but doesn't stain most fungi: exceptions are Aspergillus spp. and the Mucorales.

Grocott methenamine silver (GMS)

stains fungal cell wall black

Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)

stains polysaccharide component of fungal cell wall magenta

 

Selected specific stains

India ink

"negative" stain that outlines the polysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus sp: not as sensitive as Ag detection for cryptococcal meningitis: some strains are reportedly acapsular.

Mucicarmine

can be used to stain mucopolysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus sp.: also stains Blastornyces and Rhinospondiurn

Fontana-Masson

silver stain used to detect melanin pigment in cell walls of Cyptococcus

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with a complaint of irregular fever with chills. He gives the history that he feels a fever spike every 3 rd day. On complete blood count examination, there is Hb 10.5 g/dL. This type of relapse is common with which type of plasmodium species?

options.label: B
options.text: Filamentous fungi with branching at acute angles and conidia

questions.correct_answer: C. Budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae

questions.text: Which of the following organisms, commonly found in the excreta of certain avian species, is an obligate aerobe that can form both yeast and filamentous forms, and is characterized by the presence of a large polysaccharide capsule that can evade host defenses?
questions.explanation:
Fungal Pathogen
  • Cryptococcus neoformans, encapsulated yeast belonging to the phylum Basidiomycota

Pathogenicity
  • Opportunistic pathogen causing infections in individuals with compromised immune systems

Associated Diseases
  • Meningitis (especially in individuals with HIV/AIDS)
  • Pneumonia
  • Skin infections
  • Bone infections

Transmission
  • Inhalation of spores from the environment, especially from bird droppings

Prevention
  • Reduce exposure to contaminated environments and take appropriate precautions

Clinical Manifestations
  • Pulmonary cryptococcosis
  • Meningitis
  • Skin and soft tissue infections
  • Disseminated infections

Symptoms
  • Vary based on the type of infection and can include 
    • Cough
    • Chest pain
    • Shortness of breath
    • Fever
    • Headache

Diagnosis
  • Identification of organism through 
    • Microscopy and culture of clinical samples
    • Detection of capsular antigen

Treatment
  • Antifungal medications including amphotericin B
  • Fluconazole, and flucytosine

questions.text: In microbiology, MacConkey Agar is a selective and differential media commonly used for the isolation and identification of enteric bacteria. Which of the following statements about MacConkey Agar is true?

options.label: A
options.text: MacConkey Agar is a type of blood agar that is used to differentiate between different types of Streptococcus bacteria.

options.label: B
options.text: MacConkey Agar is a selective media that only allows for the growth of Gram-negative bacteria.

options.label: C
options.text: MacConkey Agar contains bile salts and crystal violet, which inhibit the growth of non-enteric bacteria.

options.label: D
options.text: MacConkey Agar can be used to identify Staphylococcus aureus based on the presence of coagulase.

questions.correct_answer: B. MacConkey Agar is a selective media that only allows for the growth of Gram-negative bacteria.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of HIV infection presents with complaints of cough and shortness of breath for the past two weeks. On physical examination, fine crepitations are heard in the lung fields. A chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The patient's CD4+ count is found to be < 200/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

On physical examination, her blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg and her heart rate is 120 beats per minute. She reports having used a menstrual cup for the first time during her last menstrual period. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's illness?
Which of the following is an indication for adjuvant chemotherapy after mastectomy?

options.label: A

An 18-year-old boy came to your hospital with complaints of severe abdominal pain. On examination, several new bruises were all over the body. He gives a history of being bullied and punched in the abdomen multiple times forcefully by his classmate . His blood pressure is 140/100 mmHg, and his pulse rate is 102 per minute. The patient is afebrile. Which of the following should be the next step in managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Component Actions
Primary Assessment

1. Ensure scene safety. 2. Assess the patient's level of consciousness. 3. Check for airway patency. 4. Assess breathing and administer oxygen if needed. 5. Check circulation and control bleeding. 6. Rapid head-to-toe assessment.
Vital Signs 1. Monitor heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation. 2. Establish IV access for fluids and medications. 3. Insert cardiac monitor if needed.
Imaging Studies 1. Perform appropriate X-rays (e.g., chest, pelvis) as needed. 2. Consider FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) ultrasound. 3. CT scans for more detailed evaluation.
Fluid Resuscitation 1. Initiate fluid resuscitation with crystalloids (e.g., normal saline, Ringer's lactate). 2. Use blood products if indicated. 3. Titrate fluids to maintain adequate perfusion.
Pain Management Administer appropriate analgesia and consider pain scales for monitoring. Use caution with narcotics in the setting of possible abdominal injury.
Head Injury 1. Assess Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS). 2. Monitor closely for signs of intracranial bleeding or raised intracranial pressure (ICP). 3. Consider CT head if needed.
Cervical Spine Injury Immobilize the cervical spine until cleared based on clinical assessment or imaging. Follow appropriate guidelines for spine clearance.
Abdominal Evaluation Perform focused abdominal examination. Consider CT sca an for abdominal trauma if indicated.
Pelvic Fracture Stabilize unstable pelvic fractures with pelvic binders. Consider angiography for suspected major vascular injury.

A 55-year-old woman underwent a mastectomy for breast cancer, followed by axillary lymph node dissection. One week after surgery, she developed a high-grade fever and hypotension. On examination, she has erythema and warmth around the surgical site and palpable crepitus under the skin. A CT scan shows extensive gas formation in the soft tissues of the chest wall. questions.explanation:
Complication

Management Options

Pain
  • Pain medications, both over-the-counter and prescribed, as needed 
  • Application of ice or heat to the surgical site Avoidance of activities that exacerbate pain 
  • Physical therapy or other pain management techniques

Infection
  • Proper wound care, including keeping the surgical site clean and dry
  • Antibiotic therapy if infection is suspected or confirmed 
  • Monitoring for signs of infection (e.g., redness, warmth, swelling, fever)

Hematoma or bleeding
  • Application of direct pressure to the surgical site to control bleeding 
  • Hemostatic agents or sutures as needed 
  • Monitoring for signs of excessive bleeding or hematoma formation

Seroma (fluid accumulation)
  • Aspiration of the seroma using a needle and syringe to remove the excess fluid 
  • Compression garments or bandages to reduce fluid accumulation
  • Monitoring for signs of infection or other complications

Lymphedema (swelling of the limb)
  • Compression garments or bandages to reduce swelling 
  • Physical therapy or lymphatic drainage techniques 
  • Avoidance of activities that exacerbate swelling

Scar formation
  • Proper wound care, including keeping the surgical site clean and moisturized 
  • Use of silicone sheets or creams to minimize scar formation 
  • Referral to a dermatologist or plastic surgeon for scar management options

Psychological distress
  • Emotional support and counseling 
  • Support groups or therapy sessions 
  • Referral to a mental health professional as needed

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a painless, rapidly growing lump in her left breast that has been present for the last 3 months. On examination, a well-defined, mobile, and firm lump measuring 5 cm is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There are no palpable axillary lymph nodes. A core needle biopsy of the lump shows the presence of stromal and epithelial components with leaf-like projections. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what would be the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Ductal carcinoma in situ, lumpectomy and radiation therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Invasive ductal carcinoma, mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection

options.label: D
options.text: Phyllodes tumor, wide local excision and close follow-up

questions.correct_answer: D. Phyllodes tumor, wide local excision and close follow-up
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

A rare fibroepithelial tumor of the breast with characteristic leaf-like projections

Causes

Exact cause unknown, but thought to be related to stromal overgrowth and proliferation

Types

Benign, borderline, malignant (based on histological features and mitotic activity)

Symptoms

Breast lump, often rapidly growing, with well-defined borders; may be painless or tender

Pathophysiology

Abnormal growth of stromal (connective) tissue in the breast, with epithelial (glandular) components

Diagnosis

Clinical assessment, imaging (mammography, ultrasound), core needle biopsy, histopathological examination

Treatment

Surgical removal of the tumor (wide local excision or mastectomy), with or without radiation therapy; chemotherapy may be considered for malignant cases

Complications

Local recurrence, distant metastasis (rare), cosmetic deformity

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a persistent, itchy rash on her left nipple for the past 6 months. She reports occasional discharge from the nipple, and a palpable lump is noted on examination. Mammography shows a spiculated mass in the left breast, and a biopsy confirms the presence of malignant cells in the nipple-areola complex. Immunohistochemical staining reveals that the cancer cells are positive for keratin and negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Breast-conserving surgery followed by radiation therapy

options.label: B
options.text: Mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection

questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

A rare form of breast cancer that presents with eczema-like changes in the nipple and areola

Causes

Exact cause unknown, but thought to be related to underlying ductal breast cancer

Symptoms

Eczema-like changes in the nipple and areola, including redness, scaling, itching, crusting, nipple inversion, and discharge

Pathophysiology

Abnormal cancer cells from underlying breast ducts migrate to the nipple and surrounding areola

Diagnosis

Clinical assessment, history taking, mammography, ultrasound, biopsy of the nipple or underlying breast tissue

Treatment

Surgical removal of the tumor (breast-conserving surgery or mastectomy), radiation therapy, chemotherapy, hormone therapy, targeted therapy

Complications

Invasion of underlying breast tissue, lymph node involvement, recurrence, and metastasis

Common Drugs

Chemotherapy drugs (e.g., doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, paclitaxel), hormone therapy (e.g., tamoxifen, aromatase inhibitors), targeted therapy (e.g., trastuzumab)

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient with a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents with a stage IV pressure ulcer on his sacrum. The wound measures 5 cm x 5 cm and is characterized by a full-thickness skin loss with exposed bone, tendon and muscle. There is no evidence of infection. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Topical antimicrobial agents and conservative wound care

options.label: B
options.text: Surgical debridement and negative pressure wound therapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Surgical debridement and negative pressure wound therapy
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Description

Pressure ulcers

Also known as bedsores or pressure sores
Areas of localized damage to the skin and underlying tissue due to prolonged pressure or friction

Symptoms
  • Skin discoloration (redness, purple, or blue tones)
  • Skin warmth, tenderness, or swelling
  • Open wounds or blisters
  • Necrosis or tissue death
  • Pain or discomfort

Risk Factors
  • Immobility or limited mobility
  • Poor circulation
  • Malnutrition
  • Aging 
  • Incontinence 
  • Chronic illness 
  • Friction or shear forces

Prevention
  • Regular repositioning or turning of immobile patients 
  • Use of pressure-reducing surfaces (e.g., foam or air mattresses) 
  • Skin care, including keeping the skin clean and moisturized 
  • Adequate nutrition and hydration 
  • Managing incontinence 
  • Education and training for caregivers

Treatment
  • Wound care, including cleaning, dressing, and protecting the affected area 
  • Relief of pressure and friction on the affected area 
  • Managing underlying health conditions 
  • Pain management 
  • In some cases, surgical interventions

Prognosis
  • Prognosis depends on the severity of the pressure ulcer and the individual's overall health 
  • Early detection and proper treatment can lead to healing and prevention of complications 
  • Advanced stage pressure ulcers can be challenging to treat and may result in long-term complications or even death

Management Options

Description

Pressure relief
  • Regular repositioning or turning of immobile patients 
  • Use of pressure-reducing surfaces (e.g., foam or air mattresses) 
  • Avoiding prolonged sitting or lying in one position

Wound care
  • Cleaning the wound with a gentle, non-irritating cleanser 
  • Applying appropriate dressings to protect the wound and promote healing

Managing underlying health conditions
  • Addressing underlying causes such as poor circulation, malnutrition, or chronic illness 
  • Optimizing nutrition and hydration to promote wound healing

Pain management
  • Providing pain relief measures such as analgesic medications or local anesthetics 
  • Managing pain associated with dressing changes or other wound care procedures

Infection control
  • Maintaining proper hygiene and infection control measures 
  • Treating any existing infections promptly with antibiotics, as needed

Education and support
  • Educating patients, caregivers, and healthcare providers about proper wound care and prevention strategies 
  • Providing emotional support and counseling to patients and caregivers

Surgical interventions (in some cases)
  • Surgical debridement or removal of dead tissue 
  • Skin grafts or flaps for larger or more severe wounds 
  • Negative pressure wound therapy for complex or non-healing wounds

Regular monitoring and follow-up
  • Monitoring the progress of wound healing 
  • Adjusting management plan as needed based on the individual patient's response to treatment

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of hypocalcemia in a patient who presents with fatigue, muscle cramps, and tingling sensations in hands and feet, four days after undergoing total parathyroidectomy for primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.explanation:
Topic

Summary

Definition

Rare complication after parathyroidectomy or thyroidectomy, causing severe hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypomagnesemia due to increased bone uptake of these minerals.

Causes

Occurs after surgical removal of overactive parathyroid gland or thyroid gland, leading to sudden drop in parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels and increased bone mineralization.

Symptoms/Clinical Features
  • Severe hypocalcemia
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Tetany
  • Muscle cramps
  • Tingling and numbness
  • Bone pain and fractures in severe cases

Pathophysiology

Decreased PTH levels after surgery leads to increased bone uptake of calcium, phosphorus, and magnesium, causing severe mineral deficiencies.

Diagnostic Findings/Work Up

Blood tests for calcium, phosphorus, magnesium levels; bone densitometry; imaging studies for fractures or bone deformities.

Treatment/Management

Correcting mineral deficiencies with oral or intravenous supplementation; monitoring electrolyte levels, bone health, and symptoms; close follow-up

Complications

Severe hypocalcemia, tetany, bone pain, fractures, hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, and other electrolyte imbalances.

Common Drugs
  • Calcium supplements (e.g., calcium carbonate, calcium gluconate)
  • Phosphorus supplements (e.g., oral phosphate salts)
  • Magnesium supplements (e.g., magnesium oxide, magnesium sulfate).

Prognosis
  • With appropriate management, most cases have a good prognosis.
  • Long-term monitoring of bone health and electrolyte levels may be necessary.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of sudden onset of severe pain and redness in his right eye. He also reports decreased vision in the affected eye. On examination, the right eye appears injected with conjunctival injection and ciliary flush. The cornea shows a hazy appearance with the presence of a small, central, white, and elevated lesion. The anterior chamber is shallow, and the pupil is semi-dilated and non-reactive. The intraocular pressure (IOP) in the affected eye is 50 mm Hg. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what would be the most appropriate diagnostic test and treatment for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute angle-closure glaucoma, gonioscopy, and timolol eye drops

options.label: B
options.text: Corneal ulcer, fluorescein staining, and topical antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: Central retinal artery occlusion, fundoscopy, and intravenous thrombolysis

options.label: D
options.text: Uveitis, slit-lamp examination, and oral prednisolone

questions.correct_answer: A. Acute angle-closure glaucoma, gonioscopy, and timolol eye drops
questions.explanation:
Topic

Summary

Definition

An autoimmune disorder affecting the eyes in Graves' disease

Other Names
  • Thyroid eye disease
  • Graves' orbitopathy
  • Graves' eye disease

Cause

Autoimmune reaction targeting eye tissues

Symptoms
  • Bulging or protruding eyes
  • Eye redness, pain, and discomfort
  • Double vision and blurry vision
  • Dry eyes and sensitivity to light
  • Swollen eyelids and eyelashes
  • Limited eye movements and difficulty closing eyes

Diagnosis

Clinical evaluation of eye symptoms and physical exam, imaging tests like CT scan and MRI, blood tests to measure thyroid hormone levels

Treatment
  • Artificial tears for dry eyes
  • Steroid medications to reduce inflammation
  • Orbital radiation or surgery for severe cases
  • Treating underlying Graves' disease

Prognosis

Generally good with proper management, severe cases may lead to vision loss

Prevention

No specific prevention measures, managing Graves' disease effectively

Eye Signs in

Graves' Ophthalmopathy

Summary

Eyelid Retraction

Abnormal elevation of the upper eyelid, making the eye appear more open and larger than usual

Proptosis (Exophthalmos)

Bulging or protruding of one or both eyes due to inflammation and swelling of the eye muscles and tissues

Conjunctival Injection

Redness and inflammation of the conjunctiva (the clear membrane covering the white part of the eye)

Chemosis

Swelling of the conjunctiva, leading to a thickened appearance of the white part of the eye

Periorbital Edema

Swelling and puffiness around the eyes, often causing discomfort and difficulty in fully closing the eyes

Diplopia (Double Vision)

Seeing two images of the same object due to misalignment of the eyes, often resulting from weakened eye muscles

Ocular Pain and Discomfort

Sensation of pain, soreness, and discomfort in and around the eyes, worsened by eye movements and exposure to bright light

Photophobia

Sensitivity to light, causing discomfort and increased blinking or squinting of the eyes

Restricted Eye Movement

Limited ability to move the eyes in all directions due to inflammation and scarring of the eye muscles

Corneal Ulceration

Breakdown of the corneal surface, leading to an open sore, which can cause pain, redness, and vision changes

Optic Neuropathy

Damage to the optic nerve, resulting in decreased vision, blurry vision, and color vision changes

Eponymous Signs in 

Graves' Ophthalmopathy

Summary

Von Graefe's Sign

Retraction of the upper eyelid during downward eye movement, causing the upper lid to lag behind the eye

Stellwag's Sign

Infrequent blinking and widened palpebral fissures (the opening between the eyelids)

Kocher's Sign

Staring or wide-eyed appearance due to retraction of the upper eyelid, infrequent blinking, and lid lag

Dalrymple's Sign

Widened palpebral fissures, lagging of the upper eyelid, and lid retraction during upward eye movement

Mobius Sign

Inability to converge or move the eyes inward towards the nose, causing double vision in near gaze

Joffroy's Sign

Inability to close the eyes tightly, leading to dryness, discomfort, and exposure keratitis

Bell's Sign

Incomplete closure of the eyelids during eye closure, leading to exposure of the cornea and eye dryness

Gifford's Sign

Conjunctival injection (redness and inflammation of the conjunctiva) and chemosis (swelling of the conjunctiva)

Rosenbach's Sign

Pulsations of the eyelids upon palpation (gentle pressure) due to increased blood flow in the eye muscles

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of breast cancer presents with a suspicious lesion on her chest wall. A biopsy confirms the presence of recurrent breast cancer. The patient is scheduled for a sentinel lymph node biopsy. She has no known allergies, and her past medical history is unremarkable. What is the most common complication associated with sentinel lymph node biopsy in this patient, and what is the appropriate management of this complication?
questions.correct_answer: C. Seroma, aspiration and compression dressing
questions.explanation:
Complication

Management Options

Infection at the biopsy site
  • Proper wound care, including keeping the site clean and dry 
  • Antibiotic therapy if infection is suspected or confirmed

Hematoma or bleeding
  • Application of direct pressure to the site to control bleeding 
  • Hemostatic agents or sutures as needed 
  • Monitoring for signs of excessive bleeding or hematoma formation

Lymphedema (swelling of the limb)
  • Compression garments or bandages to reduce swelling 
  • Physical therapy or lymphatic drainage techniques 
  • Avoidance of activities that exacerbate swelling

Nerve injury or damage
  • Monitoring for signs of nerve injury (e.g., numbness, tingling, weakness) 
  • Referral to a specialist for further evaluation and management

Allergic reactions to the dye or radioactive tracer used
  • Immediate discontinuation of the offending agent 
  • Administration of appropriate medications (e.g., antihistamines, corticosteroids) as needed 
  • Referral to an allergist or specialist for further evaluation and management

Scar formation
  • Proper wound care, including keeping the site clean and moisturized 
  • Use of silicone sheets or creams to minimize scar formation 
  • Referral to a dermatologist or plastic surgeon for scar management options

Discomfort or pain at the biopsy site
  • Pain management measures such as over-the-counter pain medications or prescribed analgesics 
  • Application of ice or heat to the site as appropriate 
  • Avoidance of activities that exacerbate pain 
  • Monitoring for signs of infection or other complications

questions.text: Eight hours after undergoing a coronary artery bypass graft surgery , a 54-year-old male develops numbness around his lips and fingertips . A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to sudden onset vomiting and nausea for the last 3 hours. It is associated with crampy abdominal pain. The patient's history is significant for an injury to the lower lumbosacral spine, making him bedridden for the last two months. On physical examination, dry mucous membranes and sensory impairment with flaccid paralysis of both lower limbs are noted. The laboratory investigations show: Serum Calcium 13.9 mg/dL Parathyroid hormone 8 pg/mL Thyroid-stimulating hormone 2.5 μU/mL Thyroxine 8 μg/dL 25-Hydroxycholecalciferol 7 ng/mL (N = 20–50) Creatinine 2.2 mg/dL Urine Calcium 545 mg/24 h Creatinine clearance 48 mL/min In addition to administering intravenous 0.9% saline, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Investigation of choice in pheochromocytoma?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Definition Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the adrenal glands, specifically the adrenal medulla, that produces excessive amounts of catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine), leading to hypertension and various other symptoms.
Epidemiology Pheochromocytomas occur in all age groups but are most commonly diagnosed in adults between the ages of 30 and 50.
Signs and Symptoms 1. Severe hypertension. 2. Palpitations and rapid heart rate. 3. Sweating. 4. Severe headaches. 5. Tremors. 6. Anxiety and panic attacks. 7. Weight loss. 8. Flushing. 9. Abdominal pain. 10. Nausea and vomiting.
Diagnosis 1. Measurement of plasma or urine metanephrines and catecholamines. 2. Imaging studies (CT, MRI, or scintigraphy) to locate the tumor. 3. Genetic testing in cases of hereditary syndromes (e.g., multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2).
Treatment Surgical removal of the tumor is the primary treatment. Medications like alpha-blockers and beta-blockers may be used to control blood pressure and heart rate before surgery.
Hereditary Forms Pheochromocytomas can be associated with hereditary syndromes, including Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2 (MEN2), Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome, and Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Genetic testing and surveillance are essential for individuals with these syndromes.
Prognosis Pheochromocytomas are usually benign, but they can be locally invasive. Early diagnosis and appropriate management result in a good prognosis.
