questions.text: A 14-year-old boy comes to the clinic with complaints of fever, night sweats and weight loss for the past two weeks. His examination reveals a firm, mobile and painless masses in his neck. Lymph node biopsy is positive for Reed Sternberg cells. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with this patient’s condition?
An 80-year-old, asymptomatic man presents with a total leucocyte count of 100,000/uL, with 80% lymphocytes and 20% polymorphonuclear cells . What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia
  • Median age of presentation is 65 years, with 53% male presentation
  • Symptoms can vary from asymptomatic to fatigue(anaemia) and left upper quadrant pain or mass due to massive splenomegaly.
  • B-cell lymphocytosis greater than 5000/µL and co-expression of CD19, CD5 on lymphocytes are diagnostic of CLL.
  • Peripheral blood smear shows “smudge” or “basket” cells
  • Unexplained fever, significant weight loss, severe fatigue, bone and joint aches, bleeding and thrombotic events, and infections are symptoms of the accelerated or blast phase.
  • Warm autoimmune hemolytic anaemia (IgG) can also be seen
  • Bone marrow cellularity is increased, with an increased myeloid-to-erythroid ratio.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain radiating to the back. On examination, his blood pressure is elevated, and he has a new diastolic murmur. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

A life-threatening condition characterized by a tear in the inner lining of the aorta, leading to blood flow between the layers of the aortic wall

Causes

Hypertension, connective tissue disorders, trauma, bicuspid aortic valve, pregnancy, cocaine use, and other risk factors

Types

Stanford classification

  • Type A (involving the ascending aorta)
  • Type B (involving the descending aorta)

Symptoms

Sudden severe chest pain, often described as tearing or ripping, radiating to the back or other areas, hypotension, syncope, neurologic symptoms, and signs of end-organ damage

Pathophysiology

Tear in the aortic intima allows blood to enter the media, creating a false lumen and leading to dissection of the aortic wall

Diagnosis

Imaging studies (CT scan, MRI, transesophageal echocardiography), clinical assessment, and history taking

Treatment
  • Type A dissection: Emergent surgical intervention
  • Type B dissection: Medical management (blood pressure control, pain management) for stabilization
  • Endovascular repair in selected cases

Complications

Hemodynamic instability, aortic rupture, organ ischemia, stroke, and other end-organ damage

Common Drugs

Beta-blockers (e.g., labetalol, esmolol), nitroprusside, opioids for pain management

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient presents with symptoms of exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and fatigue. On physical examination, a solitary, pedunculated tumor is identified in the left atrium, attached to the border of the fossa ovalis. Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis of a sporadic tumor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

Benign tumor typically located in the atria of the heart, composed of abnormal connective tissue

Causes

Not well understood, may be associated with genetic mutations or hereditary syndromes

Types

Not applicable (Atrial myxoma is a single type of tumor)

Symptoms

Cardiac symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, palpitations, fatigue), constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss), embolic symptoms (e.g., stroke, peripheral embolism)

Pathophysiology

Abnormal proliferation of connective tissue in the atria, forming a tumor with potential for embolization

Diagnosis

Echocardiography (transthoracic or transesophageal), electrocardiography, chest X-ray, blood tests

Treatment

Surgical removal (tumor excision), sometimes with heart valve repair or replacement, anticoagulation therapy in certain cases

Complications

Embolization (leading to stroke or peripheral embolism), heart failure, valve obstruction, arrhythmias

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, flushing, and wheezing. She also reports a history of episodes of bronchospasm and right-sided heart failure. On physical examination, she has a telangiectasia on her lips and cheeks, and palpation reveals a small mobile mass in her abdomen. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) in her urine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

Neuroendocrine tumor from gastrointestinal tract or lungs, slow-growing, hormone-producing

Causes

Unknown, arises from abnormal growth of neuroendocrine cells

Types

Gastrointestinal, pulmonary, rare sites

Symptoms

Flushing, diarrhea, abdominal pain, wheezing, hormone-related symptoms

Pathophysiology

Originates from neuroendocrine cells, can produce hormones, may metastasize

Diagnosis

Imaging, blood tests, biopsy

Treatment

Surgical resection, medications for symptom control, targeted therapies, chemotherapy

Complications

Metastasis, hormone-related symptoms, surgical risks

Common Drugs
  • Octreotide (Sandostatin): 20-30 mg intramuscularly every 4 weeks or 100-600 mcg subcutaneously 2-3 times daily
  • Lanreotide (Somatuline): 60-120 mg intramuscularly every 4 weeks or 120-240 mg subcutaneously every 28 days

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presented to the emergency department with complaints of vomiting and abdominal pain. He was found to be in DKA. Despite aggressive treatment, his serum glucose level remains elevated at 450 mg/dL, and his serum bicarbonate level is 5 mmol/L. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his persistent hyperglycemia?

options.label: A
options.text: Insulin resistance due to a concomitant infection

options.label: C
options.text: Insulin resistance due to the presence of anti-insulin antibodies

options.label: D
options.text: Failure to adhere to prescribed insulin therapy

questions.correct_answer: C. Insulin resistance due to the presence of anti-insulin antibodies
questions.explanation:
Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)

Definition
  • A life-threatening complication of diabetes mellitus characterized by
    • Hyperglycemia
    • Ketosis
    • Metabolic acidosis

Causes
  • Insulin deficiency or decreased effectiveness of insulin
  • Stress
  • Infection
  • Trauma
  • Surgery
  • Certain medications

Symptoms
  • Polyuria
  • Polydipsia
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Fruity breath
  • Confusion
  • Lethargy

Diagnosis
  • Blood glucose level > 250 mg/dL
  • Arterial pH < 7.3
  • Serum bicarbonate < 18 mEq/L
  • Presence of ketones in the urine or blood

Treatment
  • Intravenous insulin therapy
  • Fluid and electrolyte replacement
  • Correction of acid-base imbalance
  • Management of underlying cause

Complications
  • Cerebral edema
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Acute renal failure
  • Cardiovascular collapse

questions.text: Which of the following is a typical endoscopic finding in Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (GAVE)?

options.label: B
options.text: Linear, cherry-red stripes radiating from the pylorus towards the antrum

options.label: D
options.text: Dilated and tortuous veins in the stomach

questions.correct_answer: B. Linear, cherry-red stripes radiating from the pylorus towards the antrum
questions.explanation:
Topic

Summary

Definition

Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (GAVE), also known as "watermelon stomach," is a condition characterized by dilated blood vessels in the lining of the stomach, which can cause chronic bleeding and result in gastrointestinal symptoms.

Causes

The exact cause of GAVE is unknown, but it has been associated with various conditions such as liver disease, autoimmune diseases, and chronic renal failure.

Symptoms/ Clinical features
  • Chronic gastrointestinal bleeding (often presenting as iron-deficiency anemia) 
  • Epigastric pain 
  • Nausea and vomiting

Pathophysiology

The exact pathophysiology of GAVE is not fully understood, but it is thought to involve abnormal vascular remodeling and dilation in the gastric mucosa, leading to bleeding.

Diagnostic findings/ Work Up
  • Upper endoscopy with characteristic endoscopic appearance ("watermelon stripes" or "honeycomb" pattern) 
  • Biopsy to confirm diagnosis
  • Blood tests to assess for anemia and underlying conditions

Treatment/ Management
  • Endoscopic interventions (e.g. argon plasma coagulation, laser therapy) to cauterize bleeding blood vessels 
  • Medications to reduce gastric acid production (e.g. proton pump inhibitors) as needed 
  • Blood transfusions or iron supplementation for anemia

Complications
  • Recurrent bleeding and anemia 
  • Need for repeated interventions 
  • Rarely, perforation or stricture formation

Common Drugs with doses Used

Proton pump inhibitors (e.g. omeprazole 20-40 mg/day) as per clinician's discretion and severity of symptoms

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, and palpitations during exercise. His father died of sudden cardiac arrest at the age of 40. On physical examination, a loud systolic murmur is heard over the left sternal border that increases with the Valsalva maneuver and decreases with squatting. ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. Echocardiogram reveals asymmetrical septal hypertrophy with systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

A genetic heart condition characterized by abnormal thickening of the heart muscle, usually affecting the left ventricle

Causes

Genetic mutations, often inherited in an autosomal dominant manner

Symptoms

Asymptomatic in many cases; symptoms may include dyspnea, chest pain, palpitations, syncope, and sudden cardiac death

Pathophysiology

Abnormal thickening of the heart muscle leads to reduced left ventricular chamber size, increased left ventricular stiffness, and outflow obstruction

Diagnosis

Echocardiography, electrocardiography, cardiac MRI, genetic testing

Treatment
  • Medications (beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, disopyramide)
  • Lifestyle modifications
  • Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) for high-risk patients
  • Septal reduction therapies (surgical myectomy or alcohol septal ablation) in certain cases

Complications

Arrhythmias, heart failure, sudden cardiac death

Common Drugs

Beta-blockers (e.g., metoprolol, atenolol), calcium channel blockers (e.g., verapamil, diltiazem), disopyramide

questions.text: A 70-year-old female with a history of primary hyperparathyroidism presents with polyuria, polydipsia, and fatigue. Her serum calcium level is elevated at 11.8 mg/dL. She has no signs of dehydration. What is the most appropriate management for this patient's hypercalcemia?

options.label: B
options.text: Oral calcium and vitamin D supplementation

questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Causes

Excessive bone resorption, increased intestinal absorption of calcium, decreased renal excretion of calcium

Types

Primary Hyperparathyroidism, Malignancy-associated Hypercalcemia, Vitamin D-related Hypercalcemia, Medication-induced Hypercalcemia, Familial Hypocalciuric Hypercalcemia, Hypercalcemia of Immobilization

Symptoms

Often asymptomatic, may present with fatigue, muscle weakness, constipation, nausea, vomiting, polyuria, polydipsia, bone pain

Clinical Features

Nephrolithiasis, nephrocalcinosis, bone pain, psychiatric symptoms, peptic ulcers

Pathophysiology

Imbalance in calcium homeostasis due to various underlying causes, leading to increased serum calcium levels

Diagnostic Findings

Serum calcium levels >10.5 mg/dL (2.65 mmol/L), elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, low or normal phosphate levels

Work Up

Detailed history, physical examination, serum calcium and phosphate levels, PTH levels, imaging studies (X-ray, CT, MRI), bone densitometry

Treatment/

Management

Treat underlying cause, restrict dietary calcium, increase fluid intake, loop diuretics, bisphosphonates, calcitonin, glucocorticoids, hemodialysis (in severe cases)

Complications

Kidney stones, nephrocalcinosis, osteoporosis, cardiac arrhythmias, pancreatitis

Condition

Calcium Level (mg/dL)

Calcium Level (mmol/L)

Normal

8.5 - 10.5

2.15 - 2.65

Hypocalcemia

< 8.5

< 2.15

Hypercalcemia

> 10.5

> 2.65

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with a history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN 2A) presents for routine follow-up. Genetic testing has confirmed a mutation in the RET proto-oncogene. What is the most appropriate screening test for medullary thyroid carcinoma in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

Medullary Thyroid Cancer (MTC) is a rare type of thyroid cancer that originates from parafollicular or C-cells in the thyroid gland, resulting in the production of calcitonin.

Causes
  • Sporadic (non-hereditary)
  • Familial (genetic)

Types
  • Sporadic MTC
  • Familial MTC (associated with genetic syndromes like MEN 2A, MEN 2B, and familial MTC)

Symptoms
  • Thyroid nodule or mass
  • Hoarseness
  • Dysphagia
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Flushing (in familial MTC)

Clinical Features
  • Thyroid nodule or mass
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Flushing (in familial MTC)
  • Signs of local invasion

Pathophysiology
  • Abnormal growth of C-cells in the thyroid gland
  • Overproduction of calcitonin

Workup
  • History and physical examination
  • Laboratory tests
  • Imaging studies
  • FNA biopsy of thyroid nodule

Treatment/

Management
  • Surgery (total thyroidectomy with or without neck dissection)
  • Monitoring of serum calcitonin and CEA levels
  • Radiation therapy
  • Targeted therapy (e.g., tyrosine kinase inhibitors)
  • Genetic counseling and testing (for familial MTC)

Complications
  • Local invasion and metastasis
  • Recurrence of cancer
  • Hypoparathyroidism (after total thyroidectomy)

Common Drugs with Doses Used
  • Vandetanib
  • Cabozantinib
  • Lenvatinib
  • Retinoic acid (for advanced or metastatic MTC)

questions.text: A healthy, 26-year-old woman, recently married, is anxious to conceive and visits the physician for evaluation. She is worried that her cycles come at intervals of 28 to 32 days and not on a fixed date every month. Her clinician reassures her that such variation may be normal. Which of the following about the physiology of the menstrual cycle is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Ovulation follows 24-36 hours after the onset of LH surge

options.label: C
options.text: Withdrawal of endogenous progesterone results in endometrial breakdown and subsequent menstruation

questions.correct_answer: B. The follicular phase is constant
questions.explanation: Correct Option B

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman presents to the physician for a routine Pap smear and evaluation of her period. She has not had periods for 2 years now. She has no history of any chronic illness. She gives a history of no other abnormalities. She is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The USG of the patient is done, which shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the major source of estrogen in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Aromatization of androgens in theca cells of the ovary

options.label: B
options.text: Aromatization of androgens in granulosa cells of the ovary

options.label: C
options.text: Aromatization of androgens in adipose tissue

questions.correct_answer: C. Aromatization of androgens in adipose tissue

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a history of lower back pain and cyclical dysmenorrhea for the last 12 months. She has been married for the last 4 years and has never conceived. She is referred to the infertility clinic for further evaluation. The patient has regular cycles with dysmenorrhea. Further investigations revealed dark red to bluish vesicles surrounded by flame-like lesions on the peritoneum. Which of the following is the most common site for a lesion?

A 27-year-old woman presents with severe refractory dysmenorrhea; she says she has been getting painkiller injections for the past 8 months for this condition. The doctor advises her diagnostic laparoscopy that reveals black-brown powder burn-like lesions on peritoneal surfaces and also covering bilateral tubes, which is sent for biopsy. The report says there is a presence of haemorrhage and the endometrial glands. Which of the following is the LEAST likely mechanism for her dysmenorrhea?

options.label: C
options.text: Collection of shed menstrual blood in implants

questions.correct_answer: D. Septic seeding of the implants

questions.text: What is the appropriate statement regarding further treatment for a 58-year-old female with post-menopausal bleeding who is diagnosed with endometrial cancer and is on hormone replacement therapy for 1 year?

options.label: A
options.text: ET less than 5 mm requires no further evaluation

options.label: B
options.text: ET 5 to 10 mm confers no risk of endometrial cancer

options.label: C
options.text: No evaluation required in women on HRT

questions.correct_answer: A. ET less than 5 mm requires no further evaluation

questions.text: A 52 year old woman presents with loss of appetite and weight loss. On investigation her CA-125 is markedly raised. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?

A 50-year-old female presents to gynecology OPD with complaints of lower abdominal pain and abdominal distension for the last 1 month. Her ultrasound report reveals bilateral solid ovarian tumors along with ascites. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is done, which reveals an ulcerative growth in the pyloric region of the stomach . The most likely diagnosis is:

options.label: A
options.text: Malignant epithelial ovarian tumor with gastric metastasis

options.label: B
options.text: Germ cell ovarian tumor with concurrent gastric malignancy

options.label: C
options.text: Sex cord stromal tumor with concurrent gastric malignancy

questions.correct_answer: D. Carcinoma stomach with Kurkenberg’s tumor

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of anorexia and weight loss. On ultrasound, there are bilateral ovarian malignant masses for which the gynecologist is planning for laparotomy. On exploration, the ovaries are symmetrically enlarged with firm and waxy consistency. Histopathology shows signet-ring cells. Which of the following investigation is warranted in this case?

A patient presents with abdominal discomfort, bloating, and pain . On MRI bilateral ovarian tumors with involvement of pelvic lymph node and liver capsule are seen. What is the appropriate staging of this ovarian tumor?
A patient presents with an unilocular ovarian cyst. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Unilocular cyst

Definition
  • Simple or unilocular cysts are fluid-filled sacs that develop in the ovary 
  • Contain only one compartment or chamber.

Size
  • Typically smaller than 10 cm in diameter.

Appearance
  • Appear as thin-walled and echo-free (black) on ultrasound imaging.

Symptoms
  • Often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally during routine pelvic exams or imaging studies. 
  • Rarely cause pelvic pain or discomfort.

Diagnosis
  • Can be diagnosed using ultrasound or other imaging techniques.
  • Blood tests for tumor markers such as CA-125 may be ordered to rule out malignancy.

Treatment
  • Observation: In some cases, a functional unilocular cyst may resolve on its own without any intervention. Therefore, observation and monitoring the cyst with regular ultrasounds may be appropriate in some cases.
  • Medical Management: Hormonal therapy may be used to shrink or prevent the recurrence of functional cysts. Oral contraceptives are the most commonly used hormonal therapy.
  • Surgical Management: Surgical removal of the cyst may be necessary in cases where the cyst is large, causes symptoms, or is suspected of being malignant. The type of surgery performed depends on the size and location of the cyst.
  • Laparoscopic Surgery: If the cyst is small and not suspected of being malignant, laparoscopic surgery may be performed. Laparoscopic surgery is a minimally invasive technique that involves small incisions in the abdomen and the use of a camera and surgical instruments to remove the cyst.
  • Laparotomy: If the cyst is large or suspected of being malignant, an open surgical approach called a laparotomy may be necessary. This involves a larger abdominal incision and removal of the cyst along with any affected tissue.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with infertility and irregular menstrual cycles. She reports that she has been trying to conceive for the past 2 years without success. On evaluation, it is found that she has elevated levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). Which of the following hormones is responsible for inducing ovulation in females?
questions.explanation:
Hormonal Regulation of Menstrual Cycle

Key hormones
  • Estrogen
  • Progesterone
  • LH 
  • FSH

Follicular phase
  • FSH stimulates the development of follicles in the ovaries, which produce estrogen. 
  • Estrogen thickens the endometrium.

Ovulation
  • LH surge triggers ovulation.

Luteal phase
  • LH stimulates the corpus luteum to produce progesterone, which maintains the endometrium.

Menstruation
  • If fertilization does not occur
  • The corpus luteum disintegrates
  • Leads to a drop in progesterone and menstruation.

Key Hormones Involved in Menstrual Cycle

LH
  • Secreted by the pituitary gland, responsible for triggering ovulation

FSH
  • Stimulates the development of follicles in the ovaries

Estrogen
  • Produced by the developing follicles and responsible for thickening the endometrium

Progesterone
  • Produced by the corpus luteum and responsible for maintaining the endometrium

Implications of Ovulatory Dysfunction

Infertility
  • Without ovulation, there is no egg for fertilization.

Irregular menstrual cycles
  • Lack of ovulation can lead to unpredictable menstrual cycles.

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
  • A common cause of ovulatory dysfunction, characterized by multiple cysts on the ovaries and hormonal imbalances.

Amenorrhea
  • Absence of menstrual periods, often caused by ovulatory dysfunction.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with complaints of abdominal cramping and vaginal bleeding. Which hormone(s) is/are responsible for the initiation of menstruation?
questions.explanation:
Hormone

Function in the Menstrual Cycle

Estrogen
  • Stimulates the growth of the endometrium
  • Triggers ovulation
  • Promotes the proliferation of cervical mucus

Progesterone
  • Promotes the secretory phase of the endometrium in preparation for implantation
  • Inhibits ovulation
  • Thickens cervical mucus

FSH
  • Stimulates the development of ovarian follicles 
  • Production of estrogen

LH
  • Triggers ovulation 
  • Stimulates the production of progesterone by the corpus luteum

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is true?

options.label: A
options.text: HPV is a DNA virus that causes genital warts.

options.label: B
options.text: HPV types 16 and 18 are low-risk types associated with cervical cancer.

options.label: C
options.text: HPV vaccination is recommended for boys only.

options.label: D
options.text: HPV infection is limited to the genital area.

questions.correct_answer: A. HPV is a DNA virus that causes genital warts.
questions.explanation:
Human papillomavirus (HPV)

Type
  • DNA virus

Transmission
  • Sexual contact, including 
    • Vaginal
    • Anal
    • Oral sex

Symptoms
  • Genital warts
  • Abnormal cervical cells
  • Cervical
  • Oropharyngeal cancer

High-risk types
  • HPV types 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58 are considered high-risk types associated with cervical cancer and other HPV-related cancers

Low-risk types
  • HPV types 6 and 11 

Diagnosis
  • Pap test
  • HPV DNA test
  • Visual inspection of the cervix or anus
  • Biopsy

Prevention
  • HPV vaccination for both males and females 
  • Practicing safe sex

Treatment
  • Genital warts can be treated with medications, freezing, or removal. 
  • Abnormal cervical cells may require further testing, monitoring, or treatment.

Complications
  • Cervical cancer
  • Anal cancer
  • Oropharyngeal cancer
  • other HPV-related cancers
  • Genital warts may cause psychological distress and be cosmetically unpleasant.

Screening
  • Recommended for females starting at age 21, or earlier if sexually active; not routinely recommended for males.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common cause of galactorrhea?
questions.explanation:
Pathophysiology

Explanation

Hyperprolactinemia

Increased levels of prolactin in the blood can stimulate milk production in the mammary glands, leading to galactorrhea. 

  • Medications
  • Tumors
  • Other underlying medical conditions.

Nipple stimulation
  • Excessive nipple stimulation such as 
    • From frequent breastfeeding 
    • Sexual activity 

Hypothyroidism

Low levels of thyroid hormone 

Clinical Presentation

Diagnostic Criteria

Breast discharge
  • Physical examination of the breasts and nipples
  • Observation of the 
    • Color
    • Consistency
    • Volume of the discharge

Absence of menstrual period or irregular menstrual cycles

Blood tests to measure prolactin levels

Infertility or decreased libido

MRI or CT scan

Headaches or vision changes

Medical history and physical examination to identify underlying medical conditions or medications that may be contributing to hyperprolactinemia

Treatment Option

Explanation

Medications
  • Dopamine agonists
    • Bromocriptine 
    • Cabergoline

Surgery
  • Surgical removal of pituitary tumors 
  • Other underlying causes of hyperprolactinemia may be necessary in some cases.

Lifestyle changes
  • Avoiding excessive nipple stimulation
  • Maintaining a healthy weight
  • Managing underlying medical conditions, 

Complication

Explanation

Infertility

Galactorrhea and hyperprolactinemia can disrupt ovulation and interfere with fertility.

Osteoporosis

Prolonged elevation of prolactin levels can interfere with the body's ability to absorb calcium and lead to decreased bone density.

Sexual dysfunction

Galactorrhea and hyperprolactinemia can cause 

  • Decreased libido
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Other sexual problems.

Pituitary tumors

Galactorrhea and hyperprolactinemia may be caused by pituitary tumors

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with severe menstrual pain that is not relieved by over-the-counter pain medications. Upon further investigation, it is discovered that she has a history of pelvic inflammatory disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. What is the most appropriate treatment for her dysmenorrhea?
questions.explanation:
Etiology of Dysmenorrhea

Description

Primary Dysmenorrhea
  • Painful menstrual cramps without underlying pelvic pathology

Secondary Dysmenorrhea
  • Painful menstrual cramps due to underlying pelvic pathology, such as 
  • Endometriosis
  • Adenomyosis
  • Uterine fibroids

Endometriosis
  • Condition in which tissue similar to the lining of the uterus grows outside the uterus, causing pain and inflammation

Adenomyosis
  • Condition in which the lining of the uterus grows into the muscle wall of the uterus, causing painful cramps and heavy bleeding

Uterine Fibroids
  • Noncancerous growths in the uterus that can cause pain and heavy bleeding

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
  • Infection of the reproductive organs, causing pain and inflammation

Cervical Stenosis
  • Narrowing of the opening of the cervix, causing blockage and painful menstrual cramps

Ovarian Cysts
  • Fluid-filled sacs on the ovary, which can cause pain and discomfort during menstruation

IUD
  • Presence of an intrauterine device (IUD) for contraception, which can cause painful cramps and heavy bleeding

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with severe dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. She reports that she started menstruating at the age of 10. What is a potential cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Endometriosis

Definition
  • A condition characterized by the growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus

Pathophysiology
  • Endometrial tissue responds to hormonal changes during the menstrual cycle, leading to the development of implants, adhesions, and scarring

Risk factors
  • Early menarche
  • Nulliparity
  • Family history
  • Retrograde menstruation 
  • Immune system dysfunction

Clinical features
  • Pelvic pain
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Dyspareunia
  • Infertility
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms

Diagnostic tools
  • Transvaginal ultrasound
  • MRI
  • Laparoscopy
  • Biopsy

Treatment options
  • Pain management
  • Hormonal therapy
  • Surgical excision
  • Assisted reproductive techniques

Complications
  • Infertility
  • Chronic pain
  • Increased risk of ovarian & endometrial cancer

Importance of early intervention
  • Early diagnosis and treatment can improve pain, prevent complications, and increase the chances of successful fertility treatments

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a sudden onset of severe lower abdominal pain, vomiting, and fever. Pelvic examination reveals cervical motion tenderness, adnexal tenderness, and a palpable pelvic mass. Imaging studies reveal a large complex cystic mass with internal echoes, peripheral vascularity, and fluid-filled spaces. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Characteristics

Size

Typically 3-5 cm in diameter

Occurrence

Can occur on one or both ovaries

Symptoms

Often asymptomatic, but can cause pelvic pain or discomfort

Diagnosis

Usually detected on ultrasound imaging during routine gynecological exams
 

Early detection and treatment of fibroids can help prevent complications and improve quality of life. Women with fibroids should discuss their treatment options with their healthcare provider and make an informed decision based on their individual needs and goals.

Causes

Description

Corpus luteal cysts develop as a result of hormonal changes during the menstrual cycle.

Hormonal Changes

Develops when the corpus luteum does not dissolve as it should after releasing the egg, leading to accumulation of fluid and cyst formation.

Ovulation

Can occur during ovulation when a corpus luteum is formed

Fertility Treatments

Can be caused by fertility treatments that stimulate ovulation

Diagnosis and Treatment

Description

Diagnosis and treatment of corpus luteal cysts depends on their size, symptoms, and potential complications.

Diagnosis

Typically diagnosed through ultrasound imaging or other imaging tests

Observation

Most cysts are small and resolve on their own without treatment

Medications

Pain medications, hormonal birth control, or hormonal supplements may be prescribed to manage symptoms or regulate the menstrual cycle

Surgery

In rare cases, surgery may be necessary to remove the cyst or affected ovary

Complications

Description

Although most corpus luteal cysts are harmless, they can cause complications in rare cases.

Rupture

The cyst can rupture, causing sudden and severe abdominal pain and bleeding

Torsion

The cyst can cause the ovary to twist, cutting off its blood supply and causing severe pain and potential tissue damage

Infertility

In rare cases, recurrent corpus luteal cysts may cause fertility problems

Cancer

Corpus luteal cysts are not cancerous, but in rare cases, they can be associated with ovarian cancer.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for stage II cervical carcinoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymph node dissection

questions.correct_answer: A. Radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymph node dissection
questions.explanation:
Cervical carcinoma

Definition
  • Cervical carcinoma is a type of cancer that starts in the cells of the cervix, the lower part of the uterus that connects to the vagina.

Causes
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, particularly by high-risk types such as HPV 16 and HPV 18. 
  • Other risk factors include smoking, having multiple sexual partners, and a weakened immune system.

Symptoms
  • Early-stage cervical cancer may not cause any symptoms, but later stages may cause 
    • Abnormal vaginal bleeding
    • Pain during sex
    • Pelvic pain
    • Unusual vaginal discharge.

Diagnosis
  • Regular screening with Pap tests and HPV DNA tests can detect abnormal cervical cells before they become cancerous. 
  • Further diagnostic tests may include a colposcopy, biopsy, or imaging tests.

Treatment
  • Treatment options for cervical cancer depend on the stage of the cancer and may include 
    • Surgery
    • Radiation therapy
    • Chemotherapy
    • Or a combination of these.

Prevention
  • The HPV vaccine can protect against the types of HPV that are most likely to cause cervical cancer. 
  • Other prevention measures include practicing safe sex, getting regular cervical cancer screenings, and not smoking.

Vary depending on the size and location of the mass, may include abdominal pain, bloating, and irregular menstrual periods

Hormonal disorder characterized by multiple small cysts on the ovaries, hyperandrogenism, and insulin resistance

questions.text: What is the main underlying cause of androgen excess in polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)?
questions.explanation:
Androgen Excess in Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)

Definition
  • A hormonal disorder in women characterized by the presence of androgen excess and multiple cysts on the ovaries

Main Cause
  • Increased insulin resistance, which leads to hyperinsulinemia
  • Increased production of androgens in the ovaries

Other Contributing Factors
  • Overproduction of luteinizing hormone (LH)
  • Inflammation
  • Genetic factors

Symptoms
  • Hirsutism (excessive hair growth), acne, irregular menstrual cycles, weight gain, and infertility

Treatment
  • Lifestyle changes (diet and exercise)
  • Medications (such as oral contraceptives, anti-androgens, and insulin-sensitizing agents)
  • surgery (ovarian drilling)

Complications
  • Type 2 diabetes
  • Cardiovascular disease
  • Endometrial cancer

questions.text: A community medicine intern was asked to compare two study designs. What is the similarity between Cross-sectional study design and Ecological study design?

options.label: A
options.text: Both studies are done at a point of time

options.label: C
options.text: Both are based on primary data

options.label: D
options.text: The unit of study is the population

questions.correct_answer: A. Both studies are done at a point of time
questions.explanation:
Cross-Sectional Study Ecological Study
Both studies are done at a point of time
  • This study is based on primary data i.e. collected by the Investigator himself from House to House.
  • It provides “Prevalence”, so Also known as Prevalence Study
  • It is also known as the “SNAPSHOT Study”.
  • This study is based on Secondary Data i.e. Collected data from the records of the hospital. Data is not collected by Investigator himself.
  • It is used in Nutritional Surveys
  • The strength of association/prevalence cannot be calculated.
  • The unit of study is population and results are extrapolated and projected not on Individuals but on the total population.
  • This drawback is known as the “Ecological Fallacy”.

questions.text: A pregnant woman who received the COVID-19 vaccine during her second trimester is diagnosed with COVID-19. Which of the following statements is true regarding the transmission of COVID-19 in pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: The risk of vertical transmission of COVID-19 is higher in vaccinated pregnant women compared to unvaccinated pregnant women.

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of horizontal transmission of COVID-19 to household contacts is lower in vaccinated pregnant women compared to unvaccinated pregnant women.

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of horizontal transmission of COVID-19 to healthcare workers is higher in vaccinated pregnant women compared to unvaccinated pregnant women.

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of horizontal transmission of COVID-19 to household contacts and healthcare workers is higher in vaccinated pregnant women compared to unvaccinated pregnant women.

questions.correct_answer: B. The risk of horizontal transmission of COVID-19 to household contacts is lower in vaccinated pregnant women compared to unvaccinated pregnant women.
questions.explanation:
Epidemiological Information

Description

Virus name
  • SARS-CoV-2

Disease name
  • COVID-19

Transmission
  • Person-to-person via respiratory droplets and contact with contaminated surfaces

Incubation period
  • 2-14 days

Symptomatic period
  • Typically 1-2 weeks, can range from asymptomatic to severe illness

Common symptoms
  • Fever, cough, shortness of breath, fatigue, body aches

Severe symptoms
  • Pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), septic shock

Mortality rate
  • Varies by age, comorbidities, and location, but estimated to be between 0.5-3%

Risk factors
  • Advanced age
  • Underlying medical conditions (e.g. diabetes, heart disease, obesity)
  • Immunocompromised status

Prevention
  • Vaccination
  • Wearing masks
  • Practicing physical distancing
  • Frequent hand hygiene
  • Avoiding large gatherings

Diagnosis
  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of respiratory specimens

Treatment
  • Supportive care for mild to moderate cases
  • Supplemental oxygen and mechanical ventilation for severe cases
  • Experimental therapies (e.g. remdesivir, monoclonal antibodies)

Maternal risks
  • Pregnant women are at higher risk for severe illness and death from COVID-19 compared to non-pregnant women.
  • Risk factors include 
    • Older maternal age
    • Obesity
    • Preexisting medical conditions.
